title: Cardiac Power Output (CPO)
description: Calculates cardiac power output, the rate of energy output of the heart. Integrates both pressure and flow components of cardiac work. Strong hemodynamic predictor of mortality in cardiogenic shock.

parameters.name: right_atrial_pressure
parameters.description: Right atrial pressure in mmHg (optional, for original Tan formula)

result.name: cardiac_power_output
result.description: Cardiac power output measurements using standard and original formulas

ranges.interpretation: CPO <0.6W indicates severe ventricular dysfunction with poor prognosis. High risk for mortality in cardiogenic shock. Consider aggressive interventions and mechanical support.
CPO 0.6-1.0W indicates moderately reduced cardiac function. Monitor closely and optimize medical therapy. Consider inotropic support.
CPO ≥1.0W indicates adequate cardiac function. Normal resting CPO is approximately 1W. Exercise can increase CPO up to 6W.

references: Tan LB. Cardiac pumping capability and prognosis in heart failure. Lancet. 1986 Dec 13;2(8520):1360-3. doi: 10.1016/s0140-6736(86)92002-6.

Fincke R, Hochman JS, Lowe AM, et al. Cardiac power is the strongest hemodynamic correlate of mortality in cardiogenic shock: a report from the SHOCK trial registry. J Am Coll Cardiol. 2004 Jul 21;44(2):340-8. doi: 10.1016/j.jacc.2004.03.060.

Mendoza DD, Cooper HA, Panza JA. Cardiac power output predicts mortality across a broad spectrum of patients with acute cardiac disease. Am Heart J. 2007 Mar;153(3):366-70. doi: 10.1016/j.ahj.2006.11.014.

Williams SG, Cooke GA, Wright DJ, et al. Peak exercise cardiac power output; a direct indicator of cardiac function strongly predictive of prognosis in chronic heart failure. Eur Heart J. 2001 Aug;22(16):1496-503. doi: 10.1053/euhj.2000.2547.
formula: Standard CPO = (MAP × CO) / 451. Original Tan formula: CPO-RAP = [(MAP - RAP) × CO] / 451. Where MAP = mean arterial pressure (mmHg), CO = cardiac output (L/min), RAP = right atrial pressure (mmHg), 451 = conversion constant
notes: CPO is the strongest hemodynamic predictor of mortality in cardiogenic shock
Normal resting CPO is approximately 1.0 Watt
CPO <0.6W indicates severe ventricular dysfunction with poor prognosis
Exercise can increase CPO reserve up to 6 Watts
Original Tan 1986 formula included right atrial pressure (RAP) component
Including RAP provides better prognostic performance, especially in elevated filling pressures
Standard formula (without RAP) may overestimate CPO in cardiogenic shock
Used for initial risk stratification and tracking response to therapy
Not validated for noncardiogenic or pure distributive shock
Constant 451 converts pressure-flow product to normal resting CPO of 1.0W
Can guide inotrope titration to achieve target CPO >0.6W
